The penmanship my children (now ages 10 and 13) have been taught in school will suffice. It is neat, efficient and legible. There is no need to require them to become proficient in a second, archaic form of handwriting. Requiring children to learn how to read and write cursive at this point in history seems about as useful as requiring them to learn Fraktur or calligraphy. Once elementary school children have mastered standard penmanship a more effective use of school time would be to provide instruction and practice in using a keyboard.

The top two reasons cats are turned into shelters are house soiling and aggression (biting). It is a well-known fact that declawed cats are deprived of their main form of defense (claws), and resort to biting. Additionally, it is painful for many declawed cats to dig in a litter box. Hence, house soiling. Shelters I have volunteered at have quite a few declawed cats come in due to these reasons, declawing being the source of these issues. Pet owners who want to declaw a cat should not have a cat--period. If you want to protect your furniture, do not own a cat. Cats naturally scratch. If dog owners don't want their animal to jump on their couches or beds, do they remove a dog's leg? If dog owners don't want a dog to bark, is debarking humane? It's the same thing as declawing a cat. Just don't have one.

I find the comment section indispensable especially when reading an opinion piece in culling the purported facts with other website links, pointing out sloppy reasoning or offering an alternative opinion. Sometimes an article is not complete without the comment section, it is an alternate universe of editors, and though this maybe disconcerting for the authors, I have to imagine it makes them better journalists and writers.

Mr. Perry makes a very reasonable argument, but I think there are very few Spud Webbs out there anymore. Most of the pros are probably a good 6 inches taller than they were even 20 or 25 years ago, let alone 100, so you would think raising the rim is a reasonable alternative. I do appreciate his concern about the amount of time to adjust to the change, but I suspect that really talented and conditioned atheletes will find a way to make it work pretty rapidly.

A SINGLE PAYOR Plan such as they have in Germany, England and France, holds the potential for being a functional alternative for the US. But we are stuck with a crazy quilt of 50 different states each vying for its own version of Obamacare, anti-Obamacare or whatever else title they wish to dream up. You don't hear great upheavals from those receiving Medicare. It works. It's imperfect. Anything human is imperfect. That's evidence that a single payor program is already working here and can be expanded upon.

This is from the study that this writer Christie Wilcox cited about Organic farms being less "efficient." "We found crop yields to be 20% lower in the organic systems, although input of fertilizer and energy was reduced by 34 to 53% and pesticide input by 97%. Enhanced soil fertility and higher biodiversity found in organic plots may render these systems less dependent on external inputs." With the reduction in energy and pesticides they seem pretty efficient to me. All organic practices are not equal. Organic systems that "stack" crops like growing mushrooms beneath orchards or ducks and fish being raised along side rice patties are way more "efficient" than conventional. Science does prove organics are healthier and safer. The irony of that recent Stanford paper is that it showed there are less antibiotic resistant bacteria on organic meat and less pesticide residue on produce. Produce grown in biologically active soil, which is achieved using organic soil building methods, does have more testable ultra-trace minerals. Scientists are only now understanding how important these minerals are to human health. The holes in Christie Wilcox's argument are far and wide.

Goofy beyond belief. Religious beliefs are just that...beliefs. To whatever degree a religious practice is benign, it should be allowed. When the practice impinges upon public health or safety, it must be curtailed for the benefit of the entire society. Our tradition is not to concern ourselves with how people worship their god (or choose not to worship at all.) All are free to practice their religion as they see fit. Accordingly, we should also be able to choose to be free of religion when it impinges upon public health or well being. Permitting religious beliefs to trump science is antithetical to our secular culture.

"One of the main pillars of Syriza's economic program is the creation of 300,000 new jobs for the unemployed under a direct public employment scheme." Anyone who thinks that expanding public employment in Greece is a good idea should migrate to Greece. There are already more public employees in Greece than just about anywhere else in the world and you propose to put more people on the public payroll? As it is, many government employees do not have any meaningful assignments and you want the Greek government to hire more people? What you are actually proposing is a massive expansion of welfare payments to the unemployed in Greece except that you claim to have given these people a job and so instead of social welfare you want the world to think of it as job creation. Here is a freebie for you: playing with words do not change economic realities. Greece cannot afford it and it is precisely such policies that created this mess in the first place.

Abuse of birthright citizenship is not restricted only to undocumented immigrants. I see many H-1B holders (possibly with pending green card applications, but that's irrelevant) get married and have children in the US. Their children get US passports. This is a calculated move to take advantage of birthright citizenship. In some cases, they get married to people who aren't even in the US, bring the spouse over legally on H-4, and have children here.

Another tragedy of the commons. For newspapers, restricting access to paid subscribers would probably end this problem, or ameliorate it enough. Non-subscribers could solve math problems or the like before being given access to make comments, one problem solved per comment made. Skin needs to be in the game or there are no rules.

While the government wants us to eat healthy, it is very true that organic foods are outrageously priced for the small amount of food we recieve. Yes, when going to McDonald's and getting 5 things off of the dollar menu you get more bang for your buck. However, that is one reason why America is in such bad shape literally and figuratively. Obviously organic products are healthier for you than genetically enhanced ones. The cows that produce the normal milk we drink are fed steroids to be able to produce more milk than naturally possible. Therefore, we are not consuming 100% pure milk. That can cut down the natural nutrients we would be recieving if everyone housed their own cow. So, this article couldn't be any more incorrect by saying that America is worse off consuming organic products. If everyone decided to trade out a bag of Lay's for some all natural vegetable chips, consumption sizes would be cut down and health could be improved.

An incredible amount of time can be lost to technical issues with online classes (and with computers in classrooms). The discussion board doesn't open, links are broken, my browser won't open this or that page, the teacher can't find the file, we can't submit our work because the files are too big, students can't figure out how to make/open/save files, printers run out of ink, presentations disappear, and on and on and ON. One of these semesters I want to do research to see if using computers really does save time in the classroom. I suspect that it's not as much time as everyone seems to think.

"Even beauty and mommy blogs and movie review websites are littered with the scourge of the earth, desperately seeking attention." On the other side, TV shows, websites and even, yes this site, reward people for their comments and/or tweets be they nasty or nice. The comments are free content for the sites - they don't have to pay people when they lift what they want out of them. So if you kill the comments, what will replace them? Actual paid professional writers? OMG!!! YES PLEASE!

The chef's vision, blah, blah, blah. Every so often at at otherwise decent restaurant, the chef of the moment under salts the food. Just plain and simple, they miss the mark. I understand, that happens, the food doesn't turn up on the table just as the chef intended when the dish was created. I am talking about a case in which the executive chef, were she tasting the food herself, would consider it under seasoned. In such a case when I am spending $38 on an entree, would the restaurant prefer I send it back and refuse to pay, or eat it and grumble about it on Yelp, or simply shake a little salt on it and be happy and tip well? It is the restaurant's choice. In addition, salt is not cinnamon. It is an absurd comparison. An under salted dish is unpalatable. A dish with less than optimal cinnamon is still fine.

"Ultimately, it might be a control thing. I want to have as much say in our guest experience as possible, even when it comes down to the salt." Yes, it's a control thing. But I find it incredible that the cook thinks he should be able to control the customer. America can be a strange place, if your free to run around with guns, but not free to put salt on your food. Maybe your constitution needs a salt amendment.

So if Christians elevate religious law over civil law, it is freedom. If Muslims do this, it is fascism. If one individual prevents lifesaving care from being administered to another individual, that is a crime. Why should shared DNA come into the discussion?

So if Christians elevate religious law over civil law, it is freedom. If Muslims do this, it is fascism. If one individual prevents lifesaving care from being administered to another individual, that is a crime. Why should shared DNA come into the discussion?

I'm curious when Democrats pull the lever for Dem candidates is this the type of thing they have in mind as they vote? It appears to me the Dems are willing to stoop to any manner of lawlessness to accommodate people who have flaunted are immigration laws. I can't imagine many people beyond those that stand to benefit from this being supportive.

I love national parks. Growing up in India, unspoiled green spaces were really foreign, and National Parks are America's best idea for generations to come. I visit Mt Ranier National Park several times as it is almost in my backyard. I am struck by the damage that visitors can inflict on the fragile wild flower meadows in their eagerness and zeal to enjoy the beauty. While better funding and visitor resources such as mass transportation could help, something we can all do is volunteer at a NP for a few days a year. This will go a long way in relieving the already stretched NP resources and the benefit to the volunteer citizen is priceless. Picking up trash, pulling weeks, cataloging wildflowers, roving the meadows helping visitors, etc. can help give back to our country's best idea and recharge our batteries all in one act!!

I don't think I would even read the Times any more if it didn't have a moderated comments section. I don't trust the reporting any more without checking the comments. I am sure the Times knows how much valuable content they are getting for free.

In our 40 and some years of marriage, we have had 9 cats, and declawed all of them. Our cats are strictly indoor cats and most of them have lived 10 plus years (One even lived to 20!) without any of the behavioral problems described in this article. Our first cat destroyed our furniture and did not respond to all the behavior modification hints in these articles. If people are not allowed to declaw, I fear even more cats will be euthanized. We love our cats, and I don't think declawing them was an awful thing.

Forcing austerity on Greece has depressed the economy even further than it was, caused much human suffering and pretty much assured that the folks holding Greek debt will get less money that they would have otherwise. Perhaps it has worked as a morality play, but not as economics. This commentator is right, it'll be difficult for Syriza to do worse.

Wow. So at the same time as Hillary, Bill, the president, the DOJ, and the FBI are all colluding to prevent justice from happening, and they're not even bothering to hide it - just plain big ol' middle finger to justice, RBG is whining that someone who doesn't share her liberal religious beliefs might threaten justice. Nice.

I agree with some sort of moderation, including blocking the repeatedly abusive. There is no need for anonymity but it does help encourage the comments from insiders on various issues. "Comments" sections seem to me to satisfy the "Ray Healey rule of debate" (my dad) who said that you should not enter into an argument unless you are prepared to be persuaded. If I were the publisher, my columnists would read the comments, or go back to blogging.

One of my favorite sections of the printed NY Times is the letters to the editor. The comments sections on the website are even more pleasing, because there are more comments than could possibly be printed, most of which are very well written. I recognize that moderation is essential, and hope that the Times will continue to devote resources in that direction.

It may have made sense once upon a time but not anymore. I am liberal thinker and I don't mean to say that we need to deport people in mass or not have systems in place to care for newborns of any status who happen to be born here. But citizenship should be a priveledge that is applied for by families or legal representation in exceptional circumstances, and it should be earned thorugh a process by which it is clear the person (or family) is well invested in our culture and economy. I have two daughters born in Switzerland, neither of whom were offered Swiss citizenship at birth because the simple fact of their birth didn't make them Swiss. Under the current system it is simply too easy to take advantage of the current law and use automatic citizenship to take more than is earned. Again, I am not saying we shouldn't be a compassionate country, and how a new system is implemented would be a lengthy, difficult task, but it definitely should change.

Single payer is the obvious solution. We have a single payer system here in the Czech Republic. I can choose my doctor. I receive good care quickly. I had elective surgery one time, received it within a week. The system works. The US system does not, and will not, even under ObamaCare, because of the for-profit insurance industry.

When I went to college a decade ago, the priced i paid for a single dorm room was less than a shared off-campus room. I did live in an older building with communal bathrooms, my room was tiny with a bed, desk, dresser and a small closet. Not only that, it gave my parents peace of mind that people in my building were enrolled students, opposite gender friends aren't supposed to stay overnight and an RA on every floor. At night if I needed to go somewhere on campus and felt unsafe, I could call the university for someone to walk with me. Obviously it you cannot afford to live outside of your home, that's that but for people to claim off campus housing is cheaper and everyone does it is plain wrong.

Hold on. Reporting concerns to police is not very effective if the police are not very well trained to respond. Very few police departments have the funds (or priorities) to provide special training for dealing with mentally ill/disturbed people. Too often mentally ill people are tasered, assaulted, or shot unnecessarily. And patients who are reported to law enforcement often feel, understandably, betrayed by the person who reports them, leading them to stop treatment--or at least stop being honest about their thoughts and feelings.

Publishing and newspapers are old industries. Publishing has fed too long from the labors of writers and readers while too seldom adding true value. Newspapers have been lean and efficient, they juat aren't capable of satisfying the demand curve of today's public. Telecommunications and transportation behaved similarly to publishing and they underwent dramatic restructuring. The music production industry is well on its way toward completing a shake up. It isn't pretty, but it is too late for publishing to control their future. Ten years ago they might have had more of a say in the direction the sector is going; it is now pre-ordained.

I've had forepaws declawed for my indoor cats for almost 40 years with no problems. Good health, friendly behavior, near-perfect use of the litter box, no clawed furniture. My guess is that if they could choose, they would prefer that to euthanasia at the shelter.

As Truman stated so many years ago, "It has become an operational and at times a policy-making arm of the Government. This has led to trouble and may have compounded our difficulties in several explosive areas." Indeed, the CIA/NSA has become an all powerful, unaccountable, unconstitutional fourth wing of government in control of the Executive and running our foreign policy to the detriment of the world and of our basic rights as citizens. The CIA has always been above the law, uncontrollable and unaccountable. It is responsible for more crimes against humanity than any other organization or government, orchestrating civil wars, coups, establishing brutal dictatorships from Guatemala to Chile to Iran, training and overseeing death squads and torture around the globe. It is past time to abolish this monstrous institution along with its other faces; NSA, NATO, USAID and put intelligence gathering back in the military with heavy, independent oversight to prevent abuse. It is time to prosecute those responsible for international crimes and human rights abuse. It is also telling that the Times, know to be connected to the CIA, didn't have former CIA analyst Ray McGovern in this conversation.

Right on! The watchword for any business, restaurants included, should generally be "the customer is always right." This is especially true with regard to tastes, and appreciation of flavors. People do not all experience the same food the same way and for an egotistic chef to imagine he has the right to determine how much salt should be put on something is ridiculous. The chef doesn't know best for everyone. So keep the salt and pepper shakers. They are the ubiquitous best flavor enhancers around--the very reason they are ubiquitous in any GOOD restaurant IMHO!

How is bashing and belittling Amazon Publishing a debate? I fail to see anything more here than the usual 'let's smear Amazon because we must stay dogmatic about modern publishing.' Absolutely ridiculous. Referring to their editors as Chimpanzees is beyond low and trying to say that you're not is more than back-handed. And why must one automatically assume that they'll dominate the publishing industry -- especially if all they are interested in is widgets and algorithms? Inconsistent to say the least, especially if everyone else is so damn good. Seriously biased article and extremely flawed logic. If taking these kind of subtle but bratty gibes at Amazon makes someone feel better and gets them a few handshakes over their afternoon lunch in mid-town Manhattan, then I guess that's likely the real end result. Bashing someone for the sake of it is myopic at best and most reader's won't come away with anything but a negative point of view.

The late Edward Abbey had a novel idea: allow anyone into a national park if travelling under their own steam -- walking, biking, skiing, etc. After all, getting out of the car is the best way to enjoy nature. As for the understandable complaints about children and the elderly not being able to travel in our parks under such a rule, Abbey replied that the kids will have their chances later (and we'll have preserved the parks for them), and the elderly had their chances when younger.

Why are the Euro-zone members so reluctant to call it quits? It was a noble experiment, it had to be tried, but it failed miserably. Why keep punishing ordinary Europeans in order to save a fatally flawed idea? Let it go. Each country must return to individual currencies. Not doing so will lead to greater and greater misery which in turn will lead to violence and loss of life. It's not worth it. Time to admit that the elite economists and politicians failed Europe. Now the people of Europe must take back their lives. Get rid of the Euro and all the hateful feelings it has engendered in what had been a remarkably peaceful and prosperous group of nations.

Only someone from a well-off family can afford to work for no pay. These unpaid internships harm the cause of social mobility. Social mobility is what keeps democracy and America strong. The possibility of forward movement what keeps Americans invested in the American dream. So I'm really against these internships in general. I applaud any means of preventing the already-rich from colonizing all the good careers in this country.

As a five year old, I watched the young Queen take up royal duties, after the death of her beloved father. In 1953, her government was still struggling with the aftermath of the wholesale destruction and devastation of Britain and the loss of a whole generation of young men....Governing a country is no easy task. It ignores the facts to imply that all she knows is horses. Having lived through some of the more catastrophic changes on this planet, political as well as economic and personal; bringing a country back from the ruins, and having been forced to make some very tough decisions, which impact millions of people, not just a few paragraphs... Her Royal Highness, has probably, more wisdom than all journalists combined.

i agree with these article because home-schooled children should have the right to play sports and venger into sports that they like. they should be allowed to play in sports teams to not only be active and do something they like but to also socially inneract with teamates. it would give them an oppurtunity to enjoy the sports and company of others around them. they pay school tax funds so they should have the right to play school sports and have a chance to further their abilities in the sport of their choice. just like tim tebow they chould become sports stats as well. why give up a chance like that?

The Christian Scientist's argument I'm sure seems cogent to her and as an adult she is free to make decisions that based on all known scientific and medical evidence are dangerous. But what religion or coherent ethical or moral code allows a parent to (in extreme cases) essentially allow their child to die when it is preventable. Give the child the right to grow up and form his or her own opinions.

Of course students should be challenged to learn another language at college. Proficiency in a second (or third) language is beside the point. The actual learning process enforces a discipline that incorporates several facets of adult education - logical thinking, memorization, multimedia exposure (video, audio, in-person interaction, etc). Learning a language creates good study and education habits.

Germany to remain in the currency union is a MUST. Period. Germany has to give Southern Europe guidance - and not just fresh money. Ultemately Europe is a Schicksalsgemeinschaft that is a firm community of members sticking together in mutual loyality.

Why is the queen's retirement even a subject for debate? She is of sound mind and body and clearly is not ready to abdicate. Most monarchs reign until death if they are capable. Charles (and William) will just have to wait.

I taught in an honors pre law program, and another prof won the student popularity contest ( $5000) pretty much every year. Of course, he gave high and easy grades (>3.8/4) using the same tests/answers for 30 years. Our pragmatic but not too bright (or honest) chair also thought the student popularity poll really measured excellence in teaching.

For me, it's pretty simple, whenever I go to a restaurant, and don't see salt, pepper, or condiments, I can rest easy knowing that a real, honest to goodness artisan is staffed in the kitchen. I know my food will come out tasting just fine.

For me, it's pretty simple, whenever I go to a restaurant, and don't see salt, pepper, or condiments, I can rest easy knowing that a real, honest to goodness artisan is staffed in the kitchen. I know my food will come out tasting just fine.

The system is out of balance, and it's the national industries with their very different output levels which thrives this diversion. There is a lot of tax-payer money which is trying to counter this, but the money, which is on account of the governments are just peanuts. The german industry is steamrolling the rest of europe, and for this devastation everyone has to pay, first of all the german tax-payers. Just look at france, their demise is now on the lever. Where should this end ? A few countries with a workforce of 50 Mio is liable for producing the need of 350 Mio citizen ? But the main problem are political and social issues. This is a conundrum, the moral hazard - unlike the US every country is liable for their own efficiency. Germany can try to drag along the rest of europe, but one reason for a success is our global competitiveness and we may fail to maintain this - to say the european economy as whole has rightly become global insignificant.

Firstly, this is a short article, Ms. Lloyd is only able to cover so much ground. For more info, read her book: Girls Like Us. Legalizing prostitution is not the answer. Someone wrote in the comments that selling your body is pathetic. It's not pathetic, it's a tragedy. And, so is buying another human being and deminishing their value down to mere flesh. Without getting into arguments about choice and consent -- Buying sex, buying slaves, selling sex, selling slave will ruin all of our humanity. Period. (Including those who stand by and do nothing.)

I have bought organic food and have never noticed that it tasted any better than the non-organic variety. I just paid more for it. Organic food is found in large supermarkets, whereas better food is found in local market with local produce. Plus I never got sick from either one - more important is the country it comes from. I avoid anything from Mexico. I just think Organic food is over-hyped and over-priced. It is not worth the extra money.

I find American men to be more mainstream, more conformist than ever. I don't find anything sensitive or feminine about them at all. Men today are not in touch with their feminine sides on any level. Life and pop culture is more all macho 24/7 competition, competition, competition like a sports event than ever. I really don't know where you think you see this loss of 'masculinity'.

Rate my Professor is essentially an internet scam to generate site traffic. I am sorry to see it getting this kind of free publicity in a serious paper like the NYT. Rate my Professor is a for-profit site. You can even post a review of someone without ever having taken a class with that person or on a class that the professor never taught. Try it. Most universities have systems for the evaluation of faculty. (I would be surprised if any do not.) They ensure that only students who actually took the class participate in the evaluation process.

Some people become addicted to alcohol, but after the fiasco of Prohibition, the United States learned that we were better off legalizing and controlling access to it. Gambling has been legalized in most states, and regardless of the current attempts to block it, Americans today already have access to Internet based gambling. The regulations that currently restrict the banking system from dealing with Internet gamling sites should be eliminated. Regulations should be established to protect consumers. The resulting legal activity should be taxed to pay for the necessary oversight agencies, and to provide assistance for those who can't simply enjoy gambling as entertainment and sport.

I too prefer to dress modestly. But a person who is not Muslim and does not appear superficially to be Muslim who chooses to wear a headscarf is not at all in the same position or even temporarily living the experience of one who is Muslim and forced to do so. I don't see how wearing a headscarf as a non- Muslim does anything to improve the lives of Muslim women.

Most Americans have the same attitude about languages other than their own, as they have about those people who might speak them--fear [and eventually hate]...Although I was educated in what seems like the last ice age, instruction in foreign language began in earnest in middle school and graduating with a bachelor's degree required competency in both a classical (Latin, Greek, Hebrew) and a modern language (French, Spanish, or Italian). With all the teaching aids at our fingertips now, the old curriculum should be revived. [And don't ask high schoolers what they think-just tell them what they should do.]

Greece hasn't come to grips with the elites that have not only poisoned their country but ruined it. Syriza's defiance of the rest of Europe (though many countries in the south will try to emulate Greek intransigence) will be an enormous, even ultimate stress test for the European Union. If only the aid to Greece had gone to the people and not the banks and hedge funds that to be paid off, things would look different. Syriza takes a cheap route, blaming the Troika, the Germans. They do not change the corrupt Greek way of dealing with their own crisis. Even in Syriza there are many who will seek profit from Greek's demise. Just watch!

Unfortunately not all schools serve healthy food like fresh fruit and variety/ flavor. So my kid spends more on food to keep away from the dining hall. Shout out to Drew in NJ in hopes someone there sees this. Not that one comment will move mountains. But I agree otherwise that being on campus for 4 years has more benefits in terms of maturity and autonomy in our developing young adults.

The only solidarity the hijab shows is with that most ancient of patriarchal male control strategies, shifting the burden of morality, family and male honor, etc., onto the shoulders of female modesty. It is no different from Orthodox Jewish married women having to cover their hair, or the in the Middle Ages married women in Europe were expected to wear a coif to cover their hair, and is nakedly an attempt to confine women's sexual nature in as small a space as possible. It stands in relationship to footbinding and to female genital mutilation, albeit at another point on the bellcurve of control of women and control of female sexuality. If you insist on sacrificing yourself on this altar to show ethnic solidarity, don't be surprised when people conclude that Islam is still stuck in the past. As Rhett Butler once famously said to Scarlett in "Gone with the Wind" when she refused to abandon black mourning clothes for a husband she not only didn't love, but despised, "How closely women clutch the chains that bind them!" Find another way to announce your religious/ethnic identity. Your daughters deserve a better message.

I would tend to agree: Poll results (no matter how ill formed the poll questions) create a public narrative that exists outside of any rigorous definition of reality. This is very much like the artificial Red State / Blue State divide, when in fact most states are clearly purple. But polls tell us Texas is full of tea party nuts, and Massachusetts the lair of well meaning but totally impractical socialists and Harvard pontificators. And ne'er the twain shall meet. This is, of course, a dangerous way to conduct public dialogue, and I lay a lot of the blame on the press, which refuses to call the idiocy of some of these polls out. The fourth estate needs to step back and find some voices of reason.

I watch enough cooking competitions (on TV) to realize that 4 chefs at a table will not all agree as to the quality and complexity of the seasoning upon the palate. Now add 2 or three courses, and remove the trained palates from diners who may be there for reasons other than the chef's concoction, and you may realize that salt and pepper belong on the table to satisfy the the varying palates of those paying to dine. I like a bit of salt on my salad, especially on tomatoes or the bread which is put on the table. At home in the shaker, we use salt that has the lowest amount of sodium (approx. 280mg per serving) and we have a grinder as well. I rarely add salt without taking a bite first. I have also had dishes where I wish i could remove salt from a dish. Leave it on the table. Those with health concerns and have minimal will power, ask to have it removed from the table.

With the costs of education FAR outpacing inflation, I wonder what these unpaid interns have to do to keep their heads above water? (Those who aren't lucky/rich enough to have parental support, that is). Of course, the price inflation of education accident. It's due to the government policy of underfunding public education. Coming from a disadvantaged background, I was simply unable afford to take on unpaid work during and after college, regardless of how much it might have helped my future career to do so. Thus I was at a disadvantage compared to peers at my college. This doesn't really sound like a level playing field, does it??? One additional point: The emphasis on internship experience on resumes allows employers an easy way to ascertain which candidates are likely to come from wealthier backgrounds...making it easier for employees to discriminate in terms of social class and race (since certain races are more likely to be represented in the disadvantaged group). Not fair. And we wonder why there are no jobs out there? Employers are filling lots of them for free.

I find most restaurant food too salty. I know this not so much from the taste but the way my body reacts afterwards. I often wake up in the middle of the night with extreme dry mouth after eating out. Since there are some people who should have little to no salt in their diets for health reasons, I'd prefer to see chefs go very lightly with the salt and then let people add salt if they wish.

According to the Centers for Disease Control, childhood obesity has more than doubled in children and quadrupled in adolescents in the past 30 years. The percentage of children aged 6-11 years in the United States who were obese increased from 7% in 1980 to nearly 18% in 2012. Similarly, the percentage of adolescents aged 12-19 years who were obese increased from 5% to nearly 21% over the same period. Now, more than one-third of American children and adolescents are overweight or obese. The obesity epidemic is linked to screen time, to kids sitting on their butts looking at screens all day, to the lack of outdoor activity and exercise. Mind and body are interactive systems and without a healthy body, there can be no healthy mind. How many yougn people these days are depressed, or hyperactive, or otherwise suffering from some mental disorder --- and how many would benefit from fresh air and exercise and time in the natural world? Mr. Bergman does not even begin to address childhood and adolescent obesity in his screed based only on personal anecdote.

Not subject to the jurisdiction of the United States suggests, for example, people born in embassies, which are extraterritorial. Jurisdiction in this context is a territorial concept: i.e. where the laws can be applied. Immigrants, Legal and Illegal, tourists, students, etc. present in the united states while pregnant who deliver a child in the United States are subject to the Jurisdition of the U.S. by virtue of that presence.

What I find regrettable is that young women in their 20's would accept rules set up by old men currently holding power in the Muslim world and men who created those rules hundreds of years ago . How Pathetic that young women who should represent the future are protecting Idiotic laws from the past . The Quran says that married women should be discrete towards other men , it never said women should be covered from head to toes. We know the rules were set up to dominate women in Muslim countries , the same way other rules were set up in Christian countries to keep women at the lower end of society . I think of all those women in Muslim countries like in Saudi Arabia , trying to have the freedom to dress the way they want and at the same time women in western countries advocating for Scarfs on every Muslim women .

While it's true that many unmoderated comments sections can become sewers (the NY Daily News section was an absolute cesspool...), moderated comments sections like those The Times actually make a tremendous contribution to both reader understanding of the issues and our political process. I would also stipulate that allowing anonymous comments can indeed be problematic, and that commentators should be willing to disclose their identity when expressing their opinion - and thus expose themselves to the potential scrutiny that goes along with doing this.

Mr. Lackman says Europe will not agree to end its disastrous austerity policies toward Greece for fear that they will have to do so elsewhere. That's a feature, not a bug. Austerity has been bad for Europe as a whole; it's led directly to the third recession in 7 years, and the risk of a long-term stagnation far below economic potential. The defiance by Greek voters should serve as a wake-up call not just for the Irish, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian and French, but for the Germans, Dutch and Finns as well: austerity is killing Europe, and should be abandoned immediately.

Voice recognition is not where it needs to be at all, especially when trying to capture back and forth across a big room. Don't have a problem with an audio record also, but have to have text. I know this is not how we are 'supposed' to think about technology, but do we want to end thousands of good paying jobs? I don't, especially when there is value over technologies that aren't good enough.

For some reason farmers (and fisherman) view making a profit as a right. Why should the rest of us support them? Farms are no more required for national security than are supermarkets or restaurants. If those businesses can survive in a free market, so can farms. In a time when unemployment is so high and our infrastructure is crumbling, giving money to farmers is disgraceful. The fact that most subsidies actually go to large agro-business and wealthy farmers is even more galling.

As an American Latino I do not at all like the separation between ' us ' and everyone else. We are one nation. Why are we so quick to say Latino families should be afforded higher education? How, in this age of political correctness, is that okay? Are we going to run around wearing Brown Pride shirts next? If white folk decided to have ' white only ' forums or ' white only ' college programs that would be labeled racist and exclusionary. We Latinos separate ourselves ENOUGH by insisting on very little to zero assimilation in our communities and on being Latin in everything we say, do, read and watch. We even teach our children to shun away from saying they are Americans like its a bad thing. College is NOT a right. As such, we shouldn't to get a free ride just because we happen to speak Spanish at home. It's an archaic way of thinking and not what the American Dream is supposed to be. I do not support segregation in any form. It creates animosity and we have enough of that already. I don't agree with the all black institutions or the Nedro college fund either.

" Congress should delay the law for a year..."? Tell that to my niece whose 17 month old toddler has just been diagnosed with a rare disease that will need years of medical care. Without the provisions in the new health care law, this family would be facing bankruptcy. I prefer living in a nation where we have the decency to realize that health care is a right. Obviously those who seem to be objecting to the new health care law have never faced what 30 million people face in our country every day. For them another year's delay is life or death.

Declawing is never a reasonable alternative,mutilating cats does not keep them in their homes just check any non kill animal shelter and see how many declawed cats have lost their homes for litterbox avoidance and aggression caused by the pain of those stumps. Note I said non kill shelters, in kill shelters declawed cats are routinely put to death immediately as unrehomeable because they no longer trust human beings and who can blame them? Declawing is despicable and it's people like you who are responsible for the millions of cats living in misery with sore stumps and claw regrowth. Owning a cat is a privilege not a right and if a person can't cope with a clawed cat then they have no business taking one into their home. It should be banned in the USA and Canada as it is in the rest of the civilised world.

Isn't it rather obvious that someone who calls himself "a reality TV critic" would have no option but to claim that such tripe has redeeming social value? "The ongoing discomfort with reality TV reveals our culture's tendency to freak out about things that scare us..." Quite right-it really scares me that a substantial number of Americans find this to be suitable entertainment.

I used to think the French were wrong to forbid hijabs in schools. But I am beginning to understand their position and agree with them. Muslims in Western countries must assimilate like everybody else. As long as they remain isolated they will be feared.

Glad Ms Grace is no longer associated with the Medicaid Commission. But as her credentials for this debate include "free market ideas for health care reform", its interesting that she doesn't offer any. Must be one of those "social welfare" groups organized to attract tax deductible funds for GOP causes. The Manhattan study focuses only on premiums and not total HC cost. Since the actuarial value is increasing from 45% today to 80% (% of premiums paid in claims) in the individual market, its going to be a better deal by definition. Mr. Roy forgot to mention that. The young male premiums before subsidy go up so much because they are offsetting higher premiums traditionally paid by women in the "free market" because they have babies, even though it usually takes two. And younger people are paying more to reduce the age penalty as they get older, much like we do for Medicare. So what's a young high income male without insurance to do (not many of these, BTW) to reduce their premiums? They can buy catastrophic coverage for a small amount to cover major expenses, just as before.

Germany leaving the Euro now? hardly fesible given the enrmous costs involved. The Greeks, Portuguese and to some extent the Italians have been forced to make sometimes debilitating cuts just to keep the union. If Germany exits, the resulting depression will once again bring to the fore the ultra nationalists in many states and no one can predict the resultant chaos that will inevitably follow. For the time being germany ie well trapped in the euro until the crisis ebbs and then the argument to separate may in all probability ebb away also

The new Greek govt must do 2 things. One is to negotiate a decrease (or restructuring to longer payment terms) of its debt. That is the immediate problem. The new Govt. may or may not be able to do this. That will depend on how the negotiations go with the creditors. Simultaneously, and very importantly however, Greece must undergo serious economic reforms. For example the creation of a land registry, a stop to political vote buying by politicians, a stop to corruption, the creation of an apolitical statistical service, a non-pollitcal civil servant based on merit instead of cronyism, etc. Does the new Govt show any signs of this (beyond rheteric)? Absolutely not. There are no signs that a land registry will be created, that merit will be the basis of a civil service, that a non-political statistical service will be created or that an effective tax collection agency will be set up. Hence this latter task will not be accomplished.

When did having 75% of the students passing a course with a C or better become a good thing? I think that a 75% passing rate is not good. Did anyone work with these students to understand why only 75% of them passed? How much did the 75% who passed understand? Were they able to apply what they had been taught on line? I've taken online courses and they were not well designed, flexible, or conducive to having a discussion. This holds true for a set of courses I took 5 years ago and for several I've taken in the last year. Having an on line course available in conjunction with a live course would be great. Then the students can go over it to see what they've missed, ask questions if that doesn't help, and refer back to it when their notes aren't enough to recall the subject matter to mind. But exclusive reliance upon on line courses is foolish.

And then what? Absent genetic testing of all children, we will see a market for US citizen fathers to stand as parent on the birth certificate for mothers without legal status. And what about the kids. How do we conclusively determine to what jurisdiction other than the US they owe allegiance too. This reasoning creates a number of problems.

Ryan Radia writes like someone who is a newbie to Android. He could get better informed by following XDA-Developers, AndroidCentral, or a similar group of people who understand Android. Mr. Radia could also visit the PlayStore and look at all the applications, like Titanium Backup, that require root access to function. App Quarantine Pro, would let you lock down crapware so that it does not run down your battery, slow your device, or spy on you. You cannot use sophisticated spyware blockers because that interferes with Google, the device manufacturers and the networks from selling your personal data. Google, the device makers, and the networks, collude to prevent people from actually owning their devices. If they really belonged to us, we would be able to install software to backup them up to an external hard-drive. We would be able to decide which applications to uninstall. We would be able to decide upon the rules applications have to follow when they are on our devices, not the "take it or leave it" practices we have at present.

Odd for me to say this since I am (a) so deeply committed to technology and computers and type super fast (>100wpm), and (b) have really bad handwriting -- but I cannot imagine not writing in cursive. Writing in print is impossible. It is so slow as to be like using a early (not even late) generation dial-up modem. And for me at least, writing does stimulate thinking in a way that nothing else does. I took all my college and law school exams in writing, even though we were allowed to type them. For me at least, not being able to write really really fast would greatly lessen my capabilities. Indeed, I've even thought about taking a short-hand class since my writing is just for me, not anyone else.

Then why do German voters continue to elect politicians that support the Euro and punish those that don't? If every friendship ended where money was involved, there could be no friendship between, for example, the former East Germany and the West. Fortunately, many Germans want to help the Mediterranean. They vacation there, they buy their olive oil from them. What's not to like?

Great quote from a friend of mine who now lives in Germany (where they have real labor laws and a better economy, social services, etc): "People who don't have to work for a living shouldn't meddle with those of us who do." 'Nuff said.

Great quote from a friend of mine who now lives in Germany (where they have real labor laws and a better economy, social services, etc): "People who don't have to work for a living shouldn't meddle with those of us who do." 'Nuff said.

I disagree. For some of us, such as runners who go out in the sweltering heat for a long distance run in the desert, replenishing the salt and electrolytes lost during the run is a matter of health and recovery, not merely a flavoring option. I can understand that sedentary people and some chefs might blanch when the see me salting my food at a restaurant. But I'd like them to realize that I am doing so almost as a medicinal application and would prefer they reserve judgment until they've run a dozen miles in my shoes.

Count me a longtime fan of the 14th Amendment of the US Constitution, for its breadth and scope that encompasses the greatest of American values: not just defining citizenship, but setting forth states' obligations, due process, equal protection of the laws, This was the Amendment that required the states to follow the Bill of Rights. Brown v Board of Education, civil rights laws, privacy rulings, women's rights, gay rights, disability protections, they all flow from the 14th. Start tinkering, and you're risking a lot more than the status of some native-born children.
Does not bother me as I have left salt out of my diet for over 40 years. I keep salt on the table for my husband nor do I salt food. If anyone wants to add it to their food they are more than welcome

Privatization of state asserts means that German businessmen can buy those asserts at a fraction of their real value and make Greece a German colony. Lachman has served the interests of the world's financial elites whose motto (Adam Smith, bk 3) is "everything for ourselves and nothing for other people." Those German businessmen and firms spent hundreds of millions of euros bribing Greek officials to buy German weapons including a set of submarines that never went to sea and are now rusting ashore--Merkel's masters want them paid for though the debt be odious. A major NY bank enabled a Greek government to disguise huge borrowings as investments; those debts too are odious. There's a story: Merkel went to Greece; the customs official asked "Nationality," Merkel answered "German." "Occupation" asked the customs officer, Merkel replied "no, I'm just here for the weekend."Lachman warns "leaving the euro would almost surely result in a massive run on the Greek banks, which would plunge the country into economic and financial chaos." Where does he think Greece is now? Oh yes, reparations for the German occupation of Greece during WWII?

The pathway to a career in medicine is designed to benefit specific areas of medicine. To be considered for admission to medical school, candidates must spend significant time and effort on research. This results in substantial free labor for tens of thousands of researchers. Also this effort is focused on research rather than more specifically to areas such as serving the community, which has a lesser role. International medical school graduates also spend months and sometimes longer demonstrating their skills to obtain a residency position. This is another area that can be abused as the stakes are high and there are few protections against abuses. Health professional associations and corporations preparing candidates for standardized tests have a great design that benefits them well, but fails to deliver the health professionals needed.

The ACA is what we have and what we were able to generate. While it is far from perfect and single-payer would likely be better, we need to try and make it work. Obama should get some credit for making any in-roads in this nasty, contentious climate. And older healthcare advancements came together in piece-meal improvements so there is reason to hope we can move towards single-payer, or least incremental improvement and coverage.
